西尔维奥·贝卢斯科尼 ( Silvio Berlusconi) 的政治生涯罕见地长寿。他于 1994 年首次担任总理，当时赫尔穆特·科尔、弗朗索瓦·密特朗等早已载入史册的人领导着欧洲的强国。将近 30 年后，他仍然领导着一个在议会中拥有重要席位的政党，曾在四届政府中担任过总理。因此，他于 6 月 12 日去世将不可避免地改变意大利的政治格局。这些变化很可能会使意大利现任总理乔治亚·梅洛尼受益。但并非没有让她面临新的风险。

最明显的是，贝卢斯科尼退出政坛消除了一种间歇性但非常严重的不适感。意大利战后在位时间最长的总理有着法老式的自我。他从未真正甘心接受这样一个事实，即在去年的大选之后，他的政党意大利力量党成为联合政府的一部分，而且他第一次 不是领导者。甚至在 10 月 Meloni 女士上任之前，他就通过狡猾地公开了一系列特征——“高人一等、专横、傲慢和无礼”——让她感到尴尬，后来他否认这些特征是她的，但令人难以置信。

当这位新领导人努力说服意大利的盟友她的政府与乌克兰站在一起时，贝卢斯科尼先生不仅提到了他与弗拉基米尔普京的友谊，而且支持他对乌克兰事件的看法（听到他的死讯后，普京先生再次称赞他让她感到尴尬作为“亲爱的人”）。

尽管已经大大减少，但意大利极限竞速对于政府对立法的控制仍然具有决定性意义。它在拥有 400 名成员的下议院中占据 44 个席位，其中执政联盟拥有 38 个绝对多数席位，并在参议院 206 个席位中占据 17 个席位，其中 Meloni 女士的多数席位为 15 个。但最新的民意调查显示它的平均值为只有7.3%的选票。据报道，它已经积累了 9000 万欧元（9700 万美元）的债务，由贝卢斯科尼先生担保。他的继承人可能不那么热衷于承销它们。

因此，詹弗兰科·米契切 (Gianfranco Miccichè) 对这位前总理的去世做出了另一种惊人的反应，他曾在他的一个政府中担任部长。 “从今天开始，”他认为，“意大利极限竞速已经不复存在了。”他可能是对的。如果没有魅力四射的领导人，该党几乎肯定会分裂甚至消失。

贝卢斯科尼晚年的生活环境让人想起中世纪苏丹的宫廷——包括后宫。像许多专制统治者一样，他高高在上的自尊心使他无法指定继任者。他留下的球员阵容对于奥斯曼宫殿的居民来说再熟悉不过了。

它包括一位受宠且雄心勃勃的“妻子”：神秘、沉默寡言的玛尔塔·法西纳 (Marta Fascina)，一位年轻的 Forza Italia 立法者，她去年在一场带有婚礼外衣的仪式上“象征性地嫁给”了贝卢斯科尼先生，但没有民事或宗教上的合法性；被赶下台的竞争对手利西亚·龙祖利 (Licia Ronzulli) 是意大利力量党的另一位议员，曾统治贝卢斯科尼先生的追随者核心圈子；以及类似大臣的安东尼奥·塔亚尼 (Antonio Tajani)，他曾任欧盟专员和欧洲议会议长，现任梅洛尼女士政府的外交部长和副总理。

所有这一切将对充斥着阴谋谣言的政党产生什么影响尚不清楚。但梅洛尼面临的最大威胁是贝卢斯科尼的一些追随者可能会加入反对派，从而削弱她的多数席位。有先例。两位著名的 Forza Italia 自由主义者没有加入由她的极右翼意大利兄弟会 ( F d I ) 政党主导的联盟，而是转投中间派政党。

另一条潜在的退出路线通往北方联盟，这是梅洛尼女士联盟中的第二大党。但是，就像 Forza Italia 一样，联盟已经被兄弟的崛起严重削弱了。对于需要新家的 Forza 立法者，尤其是那些寻求获得或获得政府职位的立法者来说， F d I是迄今为止最有希望的选择。

因此，最有可能的结果是兄弟会的优势得到加强。这无疑会受到 Meloni 女士的欢迎。但不太明显的是，她是否会从 Forza Italia 的全面解体中受益。尽管该党创始人的风格和方法预示着当今许多右翼民粹主义者的风格和方法，但 Forza 从来没有像其盟友那样激进或一贯持欧洲怀疑态度。

没有它，Meloni 女士的联盟将无可争议地与激进的、身份主义的右翼结盟，破坏她向意大利盟友将她的政府描绘成无害的“拉丁保守主义”代表的努力。在接下来的几周里，Meloni 女士可能有理由反思，你可能会得到太多好东西。 ■

中国在东南亚的影响力不断增强。美国已经衰落

乔·拜登总统希望扭转这一局面

6月11日，澳大利亚战胜印度赢得板球世界测试锦标赛冠军。尽管国家队自 1877 年以来就以测试赛的形式相互比赛，但这项赛事是全新的。澳大利亚是继 2021 年新西兰之后的第二个胜利者。

国际板球理事会 ( icc ) 自 1975 年以来举办了单日板球世界锦标赛，自 2007 年以来举办了仅持续几个小时的 T20 比赛。有一定风险。作为回应， icc发起了世界测试锦标赛。

因为测试赛最多可以持续五天，对于长时间的比赛来说太长了不切实际， icc设计了一个笨拙的系统。在两年的比赛中，球队获得积分以晋级决赛。然而，他们参加的比赛次数不同，面对的反对程度也不同。例如，孟加拉国打了 12 场比赛，没有一场对阵澳大利亚和英格兰这两个板球巨头。相比之下，印度的 18 场比赛中有一半是对阵这些球队。

那么澳大利亚应该成为赢家吗？评估他们实力的一种工具是 Elo，这是一种为国际象棋建立的评级系统，已用于各种运动，但很少用于板球。所有球队都以 1,500 分开始，然后在每场比赛后交换积分，获胜者的评分上升，失败者的评分下降。结果越令人惊讶，交易的积分就越多。 Elo 还考虑了主场优势，这对于那些根据自己的风格修改球场的球队来说是一个很大的优势。

回溯1947年的Elo分数，我们发现世界测试锦标赛猜对了：世界上最好的球队确实是澳大利亚。按照历史标准，其 1,685 的评分与 2013 年南非的峰值相似。然而，与澳大利亚自己的过去相比，这支球队相形见绌。 2008 年 1 月，一支星光熠熠的澳大利亚队取得了 1,797 的 Elo 得分记录。如果那支球队能够穿越到现在，Elo 表示它会在 66% 的时间内击败今天的澳大利亚人。

数据中最引人注目的近期趋势是自球队于 2022 年 5 月任命布伦登·麦卡勒姆为教练以来，英格兰队的评分急剧上升。在他的领导下，英格兰队在测试范围内采取了尝试更快得分并使其超速行驶的趋势。这种被称为“Bazball”的极具侵略性的风格已经取得了成果：英格兰队在过去的 13 场测试中赢得了 11 场，同时每回合得分达到前所未有的 5 分。在此期间，他们的 Elo 分数上升了近 100 分，达到 1,637。本周，英格兰将开始灰烬杯，这是他们两年一度的五场系列赛对阵澳大利亚。如果他们至少赢得三场测试，他们将成为 Elo 的顶级球队。

英格兰的激增使球场上的表现与板球的财务状况保持一致。这项运动的经济巨头是印度，预计到 2024-27 年将占所有格式国际媒体收入的 39%。英国和澳大利亚共同占了另外 13%。由于广播公司只为缺乏“三巨头”球队的测试赛支付微不足道的费用，因此其他国家几乎没有经济动机去参加这些比赛。这导致较弱的球队参加较少的测试赛，并让曾经强大的西印度群岛难以支付他们的球员。按照目前的趋势，世界上第一个官方测试冠军新西兰可能会成为未来几年三巨头之外的最后赢家。 ■

唐纳德·特朗普于 6 月 13 日在迈阿密一家法院被传讯，这在美国历史上尚属首次。现任总统政府认为，前任总统故意不当处理机密文件，危害国家安全，并提出可能导致入狱的指控。当然，更不寻常的是，被告是共和党初选中的领跑者。因此，2024 年的选举可能会变成一场让特朗普远离监狱的运动。

这正是特朗普先生想要的。在对他的起诉书甚至还没有公布之前，他的竞选团队就抓住了这个筹款机会： 乔·拜登永远无法赢得自由公正的选举，因此想把他无辜的对手关进监狱； 2024 年不仅仅是一场选举，而是一场“决战”；要么特朗普先生获胜，“要么我们失去我们的国家”；在这里贡献并成为特朗普金卡会员。

除了将民主党对美国民主终结的恐惧转嫁给原告，特朗普竞选团队还抱怨他们的人被挑出来了。乔·拜登、迈克·彭斯和希拉里·克林顿呢？正如特朗普先生所观察到的，他们都紧紧抓住机密文件，或者因粗心对待官方机密而受到训斥。因此，他辩称，对他的起诉证明他是政治迫害的受害者。

胡说些什么。美国的安全官僚机构对文件进行分类的数量超出了它的需要，以至于许多官员和政客无意中最终掌握了机密。实际上，只有当涉及到最机密的文件时，他们才会受到起诉；当拥有它们的人拒绝交还它们或妨碍司法公正时；当他们让他们变得脆弱或与他人分享时。特朗普先生被指控犯有这三项罪名。

他的起诉书中提到的一些文件是高度机密的。其他标记为“ HUMINT ”，这意味着它们是由如果被抓住可能会面临严重危险的消息来源收集的。

特朗普对这些文件的处理方式也令人担忧。拜登先生和彭斯先生的律师在他们的家中发现了机密文件，然后联系司法部将其移交。克林顿夫人的错误在于使用个人电子邮件服务器工作。特朗普先生带着至少 15 箱文件走出白宫，其中至少有 30 份标记为最高机密的文件。这些文件不属于起诉书的一部分，因为特朗普的办公室已将它们归还。问题是，即使在那之后，特朗普先生仍保留着更多绝密文件，并指示他的律师隐藏或销毁这些文件。 “你为什么不把它们带到你的酒店房间，如果里面有什么东西真的很糟糕，就像，你知道的，把它拔掉，”据报道他告诉一个人。本月早些时候，一名退役空军中校因“故意保留”绝密信息被判处三年徒刑。这是严肃的事情。

特朗普的文件也更容易被看到或被盗。拜登先生将机密文件留在了他的克尔维特 (Corvette) 旁边的车库里——它既邋遢又名牌。相比之下，特朗普先生的俱乐部则保留在他的俱乐部内，该俱乐部的数百名会员可以带他们的客人游泳和享用俱乐部三明治。根据起诉书，大量箱子被放在一个储藏室里，“可以从多个外部入口进入，包括一个从海湖庄园泳池露台通过一个经常保持打开的门口进入的入口”。

据称特朗普先生还分享了这些文件。他非常需要吹嘘并让游客感到与众不同，以至于他让一位作家、他的出版商和两名工作人员查看一份文件，该文件可能是一份轰炸伊朗福尔多核浓缩设施的计划。 “这是秘密信息，”他说。 “作为总统，我本可以解密它。现在我不能，你知道，但这仍然是个秘密。”

这些指控如此严重，以至于如果不指控特朗普先生，就等于将他单独挑出来接受特殊待遇。如果特朗普先生承认了他的错误并归还了所有文件，那么很难看出会有任何起诉。实际上，特朗普先生的前总检察长比尔巴尔告诉福克斯新闻，起诉书“非常非常可恶”，并得出结论说“即使有一半是真的，那么他就完蛋了。”

特朗普可能会被虚荣、偏执、混乱和自负的组合打倒，这似乎是悲喜交加的。但那个结局还有很长的路要走，如果它真的到来的话。此案的审理和上诉可能会拖到明年的总统大选之后。如果特朗普获胜，最高法院将被问及是否应该继续起诉这位当选总统。如果法庭同意，特朗普总统可能会寻求赦免自己。那真的很不公平。 ■

; Tue, 13 Jun 2023 15:19:06 GMT /内容/4mb5ifqc3v556f5e0r0nqc1pepsguo6g https://www.economist.com/leaders/2023/06/13/is-donald-trump-the-victim-of-a-witch-hunt How Kyiv fended off a Russian missile blitz in May

操作手册说这是可能的。但直到下达了发射命令——并证实拦截成功——维亚切斯拉夫才相信了这一点。

这位 30 岁的爱国者操作员回忆起当乌克兰防空军官意识到他们在 5 月 4 日那个晚上创造了历史时的掌声、喜悦和咒骂的时刻。俄罗斯人“不可战胜的”Kh-47 Kinzhal 空射弹道导弹不仅是可战胜的，而且是不可战胜的。但它实际上“仅”以大约每秒 1,240 米的速度行驶，这是俄罗斯人声称的速度的三分之一。 “我们知道爱国者号成功了。下一次，当我们在监视器上看到的不是一个，而是六个 Kinzhals 时，这只是继续工作的问题。”

Kinzhal 拦截只是乌克兰防空不平凡月份的一部分。在 5 月的 31 天里，俄罗斯发射了其在 15 个月的战争中使用的所有导弹的 16%，几乎是平均速度的三倍。大多数针对首都基辅。不仅是数量，还有类型都标志着一个进步；俄罗斯在努力寻找突破口时转而使用更稀有的弹道导弹，如伊斯坎德尔-M 和 Kinzhals。至少有 20 个晚上，基辅人会在清晨被俄罗斯的“迪斯科舞厅”——爆炸的无人机和导弹——吵醒。尽管声音很大，但很少有导弹能穿过防护罩。首都防空部队的表现让一些观察家得出结论，这座城市已成为地球上受保护最严密的城市。

乌克兰将其高端导弹防御实力归功于新的西方硬件。但它的防空系统——以及整个国家——得以幸存下来要归功于乌克兰人灵活使用老式苏联系统，如山毛榉、 S-125和S-300 。在战争初期，乌克兰的许多防空系统遭到破坏和摧毁。负责基辅天空的阿纳托利·克里沃诺日科将军描述了英勇的“决斗”，师长们在没有支援小组的情况下操纵火炮，他们明白导弹迟早会穿过并杀死他们。 “我们就是这样活下来的。我们在全国失去了人。这是一个千钧一发的电话。一些山毛榉机动地对空系统继续在前线后方的藏身处独立运作，即使在它名义上控制的地区，也否认俄罗斯在天空中的霸权地位。几架俄罗斯飞机就是这样被埋伏的。

克里沃诺日科将军说，基辅导弹防御系统的建设始于 2022 年 5 月。在此之前，导弹防御仅限于保卫战略要地。盾牌随着俄罗斯战术的演变而调整——西方人对风险的偏好也在增加。长期以来，乌克兰获得的主要援助是单兵携带防空系统 ( MANPADS )，例如战前首次交付的毒刺导弹。当俄罗斯去年秋天将注意力转向针对乌克兰能源基础设施的无人机和导弹行动时，乌克兰已经拥有了其第一个先进电池，即德国生产的 IRIS-T 系统。不久之后出现了由美国和挪威提供的NASAMS系统，同样具有对抗巡航导弹的能力。乌克兰的第一个爱国者PAC-3系统于 4 月 21 日上线，第二个于 4 月 27 日上线。

犹豫不决的西方领导人以需要长期训练计划为由，解释了他们最初不愿向乌克兰提供强大防空系统的原因。现实情况有所不同。维亚切斯拉夫在俄克拉荷马州和波兰为爱国者队训练了三个半月，而不是常规的六个月。 IRIS-T和NASAMS的培训协调员丹尼斯·斯马兹尼 (Denys Smazhny) 表示，即使这样也太长了。他认为，在很大程度上自动化的西方系统中，没有什么特别困难的。 IRIS-T系统比他以前操作的 Buk 系统“简单得多”：“这就像从计算器切换到 MacBook Pro。 Western 电池基本上可以为您完成工作。”

基辅的导弹防御系统是分层组织的，以确保重叠覆盖。 Patriot、NASAMS 和IRIS-T等强大的系统位于树的顶端。它们可以开箱即用地相互通信，汇集雷达的可见性和范围。但乌克兰也刚刚完成了将其他装备（包括苏联时代的 Buks 和S-300 s）整合到一个新的集中指挥系统中的过程。确定目标后，将使用最有效的导弹对其进行攻击，将其击中尽可能远离城市的地方。

基辅导弹防御的第一步是移动炮兵部队网络：基本上是在货床上安装机枪或便携式防空导弹的皮卡车。这些单位是首都抵御无人机的第一道防线。每个人都负责通往首都的飞行路径上的一个单独部门。大多数都有夜视设备和探照灯；有些有低空飞行探测雷达。

在基辅以南约 20 公里处第聂伯河沿岸的一个区域，一名呼号为“斑点”的睡眠不足的炮手描述了拦截无人机的协议。通常目标首先出现在乌克兰专有防御地图系统Kropyva上的一个移动点。几分钟后，马达发出特有的轻便摩托车般的嗡嗡声。 Speckled 说，挑战在于将传感器锁定在声音信号上。 “如果你这样做，并且你的导弹起作用，无人机就没有机会了。”

乌克兰防空官员说，俄罗斯军方总是在变换战术并寻找弱点。这可能意味着沿着一条攻击走廊发射数十枚导弹和无人机，以期当地机动部队弹药耗尽。他们有时会这样做。这可能意味着无人机在最高高度飞行，然后关闭引擎，降低它们的可见度，然后再让它们滑翔至目标。或者它涉及改变攻击的时间和轨迹以避免雷达跟踪。例如，在 5 月下旬对基辅的一次白天袭击中，首都遭到四面八方的袭击，无人机和先进的KH-101巡航导弹经过编程，可以曲折地转向目标。有些幸存下来。 “俄罗斯人必须设法找到新的方法来度过难关，”克里沃诺日科将军说。 “有些导弹耗资 1000 万美元，当其中六枚、八枚、十枚没有找到目标时，领导层就会面临棘手的问题。”

保持领先并非易事。基辅市中心上方的防御工事目前可能处于世界领先地位，但俄罗斯耗尽这座城市的目标仍然存在。 “他们想要大规模移民，让基辅无法生存，”克里沃诺日科将军说。与此同时，该国其他地区的天空受到的保护要少得多。俄罗斯可以而且确实将重点转移到其他城市——这会产生毁灭性的影响。 6 月 13 日，巡航导弹袭击了乌克兰南部的工业重镇 Kryvyi Rih，摧毁了一座公寓楼，造成至少 10 人死亡。在平民区或前线使用系统之间一直存在紧张关系。

现在的希望是在国界建立两个防空梯队，与现代西方制造的战斗机一起工作，在导弹到达大城市之前将其击落。这位将军承认，这将是一项艰巨的任务，需要乌克兰可能没有的时间和金钱。但俄罗斯没有迹象表明它打算停止其恐怖行动。 “这些威胁将在未来很长一段时间内伴随着我们。” ■

您可能在网上看过这些视频。他们从俄罗斯坦克的鸟瞰图开始，它的引擎盖上印有象征弗拉基米尔普京入侵乌克兰的白色“Z” 。手榴弹落下，有时落入敞开的舱口；有爆炸。也许炮塔被炸毁，车辆被点燃。这段由乌克兰军队发布的视频在YouTube和TikTok上的浏览量已达数千万。

这些来自前线的视频构成了一款游戏“死神降临”（上图）的基础，该游戏将玩家定位为乌克兰无人机操作员。主要目标是潜入俄罗斯军队基地并用手榴弹轰炸它们。去年，一个小型开发团队 Rockodile Games 开发了一个原型，尽管当时的内容不是政治性的。游戏发行商 Lesser Evil 加入了该项目以帮助制作，并且这个想法被重新配置为更及时。该游戏的新版本于 5 月 25 日在游戏市场 Steam 上发布。

战争为这种娱乐提供了丰富的素材。 “使命召唤”等游戏曾让玩家陷入过去的冲突，尤其是二战。 （迄今为止， “使命召唤”系列已售出超过 4 亿份，是世界上最受欢迎的第一人称射击游戏。）开发商也对入侵乌克兰做出了迅速反应，但他们已经明确表示他们的娱乐是有目的的。 “天降之死”的部分收益将捐赠给乌克兰的慈善机构。

“Ukrainian Farmy”（下图）赚的钱也将捐给乌克兰的非政府组织。该游戏将玩家变成了拖拉机司机；他们的任务是窃取俄罗斯设备。与“天降之死”一样，“乌克兰农场”的灵感来自同一现象的病毒镜头。与此同时，“哈尔科夫防空洞里发生了什么”试图让玩家深入了解轰炸体验。 “我的目​​标是提供一个让普通人的声音被听到的机会，捕捉避难所中的生活片段，”创作者 Dariia Selishcheva 说。

一些受战争启发的作品很愚蠢。 “向日葵耳光”的意义就在于名字：玩家滑动手机屏幕，用乌克兰的国花打普京先生的脸。有些令人毛骨悚然。在即将推出的游戏“零损失”中，玩家是占领军支援营的成员。他们不战斗，而是执行行政任务，例如收集死去的俄罗斯士兵的尸体并将其焚烧。

《死神降临》的玩法很丰富。但是总部位于慕尼黑的娱乐公司 Remote Control Productions（Lesser Evil 是其一部分）的首席执行官 Hendrik Lesser 表示，这款游戏并不是要美化暴力。无人机驾驶的选择让玩家远离攻击的影响；没有血腥。这些任务并非以乌克兰的真实战场为蓝本，也不涉及任何实际的俄罗斯军事单位。臭名昭著的白色 Z 是游戏在识别入侵的任何细节方面所进行的。 Lesser 先生说，这个想法是利用视频游戏的互动方面来挖掘与侵略者作战的积极感觉。

他将这款游戏视为更广泛的亲乌克兰宣传数字生态系统的一部分。 NAFO ，即“北大西洋伙伴组织”，一项社交媒体运动，旨在嘲笑俄罗斯的入侵，并通过提供“社交媒体冲击”在信息战中击败俄罗斯。 《死神来了》力求成为类似精神的“虚拟战场重拳”。无人机留下了蓝色和黄色的痕迹，这是乌克兰国旗的颜色。建筑物的一侧贴着普京先生的海报，上面写着他因“大屠杀”罪名被国际刑事法院通缉。

诉讼程序也有讽刺意味。在支线任务中，你必须找回俄罗斯士兵偷来的洗衣机来收集电脑芯片。美学是卡通化的而不是现实的。普京先生的通缉海报允许游戏玩家通过画出牙刷般的小胡子和恶魔般的红色瞳孔来“改进”他们。在某一时刻，玩家必须攻击一艘俄罗斯军舰——当它被击败时，它会沉入一片向日葵田中。 “这可能不会成为查理·卓别林的‘大独裁者’，”莱瑟先生说。 “但这基本上是一回事。这是一个模仿。它反映了正在发生的事情，而且很明显是站在了一边。”

到目前为止，反应是积极的。乌克兰摇滚乐队 Antytila 专门为这款游戏创作了一首歌曲，游戏发布后的一周内，YouTube 上的相关视频观看次数超过 100 万次。评论很热烈，人们对有机会参与战争表示感谢，即使只是在他们的想象中。 “一次一枚手榴弹将入侵者绳之以法，”一位用户写道。另一位说：“几个月来看着我祖传的家园被亵渎，生活在世界的另一边，感觉自己很无用，能把它还给……真是太好了……甚至是虚拟的。感谢[开发人员]，这是非常好的疗法。光荣乌克兰！” ■

; Tue, 13 Jun 2023 09:40:13 GMT /内容/l5ehvrlcnh9nbmj61107ol1b4oc09ig1 https://www.economist.com/culture/2023/06/13/want-to-contribute-to-ukraines-war-effort-in-these-games-you-can Is the global housing slump over?

过去三个月，澳大利亚房价上涨。在美国，一个广受关注的房价指数从 1 月份的低点上涨了 1.6%，房屋建筑商股价的涨幅是整体股市的两倍。在欧元区，房地产市场看起来稳定。 “从现在开始，房地产对GDP增长的拖累大部分应该是微不足道的，”摩根大通银行的分析师在最近一份关于美国的报告中写道。 “[我们]相信近期房地产市场低迷对私人消费的负面拖累峰值可能已经过去，”另一家银行高盛 (Goldman Sachs) 的专家在谈到韩国时写道。

经济学家曾预计房价会出现大屠杀。 2022 年 3 月，即美联储开始加息以对抗通货膨胀的月份，富裕国家的房屋平均价值比五年前高出 41%。价格从 2007-09 年的金融危机中反弹，然后在 covid-19 大流行期间飙升（见图表）。从那时起，全球央行的政策利率平均上升了三个百分点以上，导致抵押贷款成本上升，经济放缓。

全球房价肯定已经沸腾了。它们比最近的峰值低 3%，或经通货膨胀调整后低 8-10%。这与 19 世纪后期以来的平均修正一致。然而，这一集是不同的，因为它是在大流行期间价格以有史以来最快的速度上涨时出现的繁荣之后发生的。结果是实际房价仍远高于 2019 年的水平。许多曾梦想通过崩盘购买第一套房子的千禧一代和 Z 世代无疑感到失望。

在典型的全球房地产市场不景气期间，一些国家会经历一段艰难时期。金融危机后，爱尔兰房价下跌了一半。美国房价下跌了 20%。这一次表现不佳的人表现更好。在旧金山，房价比峰值低了十分之一，因为技术型人才已经迁往佛罗里达和德克萨斯。然而，它们已经停止下跌——平均房价仍会让您损失超过 110 万美元。

在澳大利亚，房价在 2020-21 年暴涨，下跌了 7%。但是，正如最近的一次拍卖所暗示的那样，市场正在复苏。位于悉尼海港灰色郊区双湾的一栋两居室平房最近以 400 万澳元（270 万美元）的价格开盘。拍卖师宣称，它代表着“一个绝佳的机会来增加很多价值”。翻译：它需要一些工作。这并没有阻止在它的大门外挤来挤去的富有人群——竞标是疯狂的。木槌最终以超过 600 万澳元的价格落下。

与之前的房价暴跌相比，没有迹象表明较低的房价造成了金融传染。银行似乎并不担心不良抵押贷款激增。他们的贷款风险较低，也没有大举购买不靠谱的次级抵押贷款证券。在新西兰，抵押贷款欠款有所增加，但仍低于大流行前的标准。在美国，单户抵押贷款的拖欠率最近创下金融危机后的新低。在加拿大，拖欠抵押贷款的比例接近历史最低水平。

房地产问题似乎也没有抑制更广泛的经济。住房投资疲软拖累经济增长，但影响不大。 In previous housing busts the number of builders declined sharply long before the rest of the labour market weakened. Yet today there is still red-hot demand for them. In South Korea construction employment has dropped slightly from its pandemic highs but now seems to be growing again. In America it is rising by 2.5% a year, in line with the long-run average. In New Zealand construction vacancies are well above historical levels.

Three factors explain the rich world's surprising housing resilience: migration, household finances, and preferences. Take migration first, which is breaking records across the rich world. In Australia net migration is running at twice pre-pandemic levels, while in Canada it is double the previous high. Demand from the new arrivals is supporting the market. Research suggests that every 100,000 net migrants to Australia raise house prices by 1%. In London, the first port of call for many new arrivals to Britain, rents for new lets rose by 16% last year.

Strong household finances, the second factor, also play a role. Richer folk drove the housing boom, with post-crisis mortgage regulations shutting out less creditworthy buyers. In America in 2007 the median mortgagor had a credit score of around 700 (halfway decent), but in 2021 it was close to 800 (pretty good). Wealthier households can more easily absorb higher mortgage payments. But many borrowers will also have locked in past low interest rates. From 2011 to 2021 the share of mortgages across the eu on variable rates fell from close to 40% to less than 15%. Even as rates have risen, the average ratio of debt-service payments to income across the rich world remains lower than its pre-pandemic norm. As a result fewer households have had to downsize, or sell up, than during previous slumps.

The pandemic itself has played a role. In 2020-21 many households drastically cut back on consumption, leading to the accumulation of large “excess savings” worth many trillions of dollars. These savings have also cushioned families from higher rates. Analysis by Goldman Sachs suggests a positive correlation across countries between the stock of excess savings and resilience in house prices. Canadians accumulated vast savings during the pandemic; against expectations home prices have recently stabilised. Swedes amassed smaller war chests, and their housing market is a lot weaker.

The third factor relates to people's preferences. Research published by the Bank of England suggests that shifts in people's wants—potentially including the desire for a home office, or a house over a flat—explained half of the growth in British house prices during the pandemic. In many countries, including Australia, the average household size has shrunk, suggesting that people are less willing to house-share. And at a time of higher inflation, many people may want to invest in physical assets, such as property and infrastructure, that better hold their value in real currency. All this could mean that housing demand will remain higher than it was before the pandemic, limiting the potential fall in prices.

Could the housing bust be merely delayed?也许。 Some past house-price declines, including in the late 19th century, were grinding rather than spectacular. Central bankers may also be minded to raise rates or keep them high until the higher cost of money truly starts to bite. Making homeowners feel poorer is one way of getting them to cut spending, which would help trim inflation.

Yet there is reason to believe the worst is over. After reaching an all-time low last year, consumer confidence across the rich world is rising again. Households on average still have plenty of excess savings. A structural shortage of housing means that there is almost always someone willing to buy if someone else cannot. And there is little sign that people are losing their taste for home offices and weight-lifting in the attic. The housing boom may have ended, and with a whimper, not a bang. ■

; Mon, 12 Jun 2023 20:16:07 GMT /content/36td9hiot0dgtsrd11acnaio2ekco4fv https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/06/12/is-the-global-housing-slump-over The South is fast becoming America’s industrial heartland

I n popular perception America's industrial heartland is its Midwest. Just look at where President Joe Biden has travelled for many of his big made-in-America speeches: Ohio thrice, Michigan twice and Wisconsin. (These, helpfully, are also political battleground states.) But take a look at where the money is flowing, and a different picture of manufacturing emerges. It is the South—a region running from Texas to Virginia—that is fast becoming America's new industrial heartland.

The shift for American factories has been years in the making. When Japanese and German carmakers started production in America in the 1980s and 1990s, most chose the South. They were attracted by a dearth of unions and generous subsidies. Nissan went to Tennessee, Toyota to Kentucky, Mercedes-Benz to Alabama and BMW to South Carolina. In 1985 the Midwest had 1.25 workers making durable goods such as cars and electronics for each one in the South, according to the Department of Labour. By 2021 the number of durable-goods factory workers in the South had just about drawn even with the Midwest.

What stands out now is the pace of change. The industrial policies crafted by Mr Biden's administration—notably, incentives and rules to boost the production of semiconductors, renewable energy and electric-vehicles ( EV s)—have catalysed a surge in investment, much of it in the South. S&P Global Market Intelligence, an analytics company, calculates that about two-thirds of planned EV jobs will reside there. The White House maintains a tally of investments in “21st-century industries” since Mr Biden took office: the South has received more than twice as many as the Midwest. The Midwest is getting plenty of new factories, too. It is just that the balance has tilted southward.

For a glimpse, visit the once-sleepy fields of south Hardin County in Kentucky. New high-voltage lines run to a giant lot where thousands of construction workers have already completed the grey carapace of one warehouse-like building and are busily putting up a second. It is a 1,500-acre supersite—roughly equivalent to about 1,140 American-football fields—given in 2021 to Ford and SK , a South Korean industrial group, for an EV battery joint venture.

For Rick Games, president of a local development office, it is a sweet reward for two decades of patience. Hardin County has sat on the plot since 2002, making sure it was connected to highways, railways, power and water supplies, but waiting for the right buyer. “There were maybe three or four semi-serious inquiries for nearly two decades, but then in the last couple of years things just started going crazy,” he says. “The phone was ringing off the hook and I started showing the site once or twice a month.” The venture, known as BlueOval SK , expects to invest nearly $6bn and to employ some 5,000 people—making it, at a stroke, the biggest business in the county.

The availability of big land plots is a crucial part of the South's recipe for success. Nathan Niese of BCG , a consultancy, says the region's officials were ahead of the curve. “They have been focused from the beginning on the ease of doing business. They have well-prepared megasites, and within 24 hours of a request can get full details about them into your hands,” he says. Georgia started a programme to pre-certify industrial sites, setting them up for fast-track construction, in 2008. Tennessee launched a similar initiative in 2012. In the Midwest, Ohio was similarly proactive, but others have been slower: Michigan passed site-readiness legislation in 2021; Illinois founded a megasite-investment programme just a few months ago.

The absence of a century-old carmaking legacy in the South also means that its officials have had a freer hand in luring firms across a range of industries, from chemicals to batteries and plastics. “We have a good diverse portfolio thanks to the fact that we were once such an agrarian state,” says Jeff Noel, secretary of Kentucky's cabinet for economic development.

The South has other selling points, too. It has cheap power, critical to battery factories that use vast amounts of energy. Of the ten regions monitored by the Energy Information Administration, a government agency, the “east south central”, including Kentucky and Tennessee, has the least expensive power in America at about six cents per kilowatt hour, nearly 20% cheaper than power in the Midwest. Awkwardly for companies aiming for greener growth, that cost advantage is predicated on the Southeast's continued reliance on coal: Kentucky, for example, generates about 70% of its electricity from coal, the fourth-most of any state. It is adding more renewables to its mix, though progress is slow. “The fundamental reality is that today, coal-fired facilities are delivering reliable, efficient electricity,” says Mr Noel.

The relative lack of unions in the South is less compelling than it once was. Just 6% of America's private-sector workers were union members in 2022, the lowest on record and roughly a third of the level in the early 1980s. But workers figure into the equation in another way: firms have a bigger pool of potential labour in the South. Texas has attracted more new residents than any other state in recent years; Georgia, Tennessee and the Carolinas have also been major magnets. State investments in worker training make this migration even more potent. A ranking of workforce programmes by Area Development , a site-selection magazine, is telling: in 2022 its top five were Georgia, Virginia, South Carolina, Alabama and Louisiana. Alabama, for example, offers free specialised technical training to both companies and jobseekers.

Geographical advantages play out differently depending on the sector. For EV s many companies aim to be near the I -75 interstate highway, which runs from Ontario through the Midwest and the South, and down Florida's Gulf coast. It puts most suppliers and many customers within a day's drive. The Southwest, and specifically Arizona, has become the preferred destination for semiconductor manufacturers, thanks to its cheap land and stable geology. In renewable energy, as in fossil fuels, Texas is emerging as America's leader, with big investments in both wind and solar power.

Might the South's manufacturing boom have political consequences? The investment surge resulting in part from Mr Biden's policies so far looks like the opposite of pork-barrel politics: most of the money has gone to places that do not favour him. According to a database of EV investments announced in the 300 days since the passage of the Inflation Reduction Act, Mr Biden's signature clean-tech law, more than 80% has gone to Republican-controlled districts. Could the presence of more manufacturing—an industry once aligned with Democrats—move their politics leftward?也许。 But as factories become more automated and less labour-intensive, their political weight may well diminish. Robots do not vote.

Still, an increase in manufacturing may reshape political priorities in other ways. Susan Elkington, president of Toyota's Kentucky plant in Georgetown, notes how companies throughout the state are struggling to find enough workers—a national concern that is especially acute in factory towns. One solution is to lure more women into work: only 53% in Kentucky participate in the labour force, among the lowest rates in the country. That, in turn, points to a need for more child care. Toyota provides onsite day care for its employees but many others in the state struggle to get similar support. “It's difficult to find quality child care, and then it is difficult to afford it,” says Ms Elkington. State funding for child care is an objective which Mr Biden failed to enact in legislation, but manufacturers may yet help push it to the foreground.

For now such challenges are not getting in Toyota's way. On May 31st it announced that it will produce its first American-made electric vehicle—a three-row SUV —at its factory in Georgetown. These cars are likely to hit the road in a couple of years, with batteries from a new plant in North Carolina. It is a $600m investment in Kentucky, but it barely made a ripple in national media. That is testament to how far the South has come. In 1986 Toyota's decision to pick Kentucky as a factory hub was groundbreaking; in 2023 it seemed like an obvious choice. The South is no longer a manufacturing upstart. Instead it looks more like the incumbent power. ■

I ndia's diaspora is the largest in the world. An estimated 18m Indians live in a vast array of countries. They are more welcome in many places than overseas Chinese, another large diaspora. Avantika Chilkoti, The Economist’s international correspondent, explores why.

; Mon, 12 Jun 2023 19:20:36 GMT /content/f7eqkink3vomkdqka31tbhvh0k2ckauj https://www.economist.com/films/2023/06/12/why-indias-diaspora-matters India’s diaspora is bigger and more influential than any in history

H AVING JUST surpassed China as the world's most populous country, India contains more than 1.4bn people. Its migrants are both more numerous and more successful than their Chinese counterparts. The Indian diaspora has been the largest in the world since 2010.

Of the 281m migrants spread around the globe today—generally defined as people who live outside the country where they were born—almost 18m are Indians, according to the latest UN estimates from 2020. Mexican migrants, the second-biggest group, number just 11.2m. Chinese abroad number 10.5m.

Understanding how and why Indians have secured success abroad, while Chinese have sown suspicion, illuminates geopolitical faultlines. Comparing the two groups also reveals the extent of Indian achievement. The diaspora's triumphs advance India and benefit its prime minister, Narendra Modi. Joe Biden will host talks with him on June 22nd as part of Mr Modi's forthcoming state visit to America.

Migrants have stronger ties to their motherlands than do their descendants born abroad, and so build vital links between their adopted homes and their birthplaces. In 2022 India's inward remittances hit a record of almost $108bn, around 3% of GDP , more than in any other country. And overseas Indians with contacts, language skills and know-how boost cross-border trade and investment.

Huge numbers of second-, third- and fourth-generation Chinese live abroad, notably in South-East Asia, America and Canada. But in many rich countries, including America and Britain, the Indian-born population exceeds the Chinese-born (see chart 1).

India's people are found across the world (see chart 2), with 2.7m of them living in America, more than 835,000 in Britain, 720,000 in Canada, and 579,000 in Australia. Young Indians flock to the Middle East, where low-skilled construction and hospitality jobs are better-paid. There are 3.5m Indian migrants in the United Arab Emirates and 2.5m in Saudi Arabia (where the UN counts Indian citizens as a proxy for the Indian-born population). Many more dwell in Africa, other parts of Asia and the Caribbean, part of a migration route that dates back to the colonial era.

India has the essential ingredients to be a leading exporter of talent: a mass of young people and first-class higher education. Indians' mastery of English, a legacy of British colonial rule, probably helps, too. Only 22% of Indian immigrants in America above the age of five say they have no more than a limited command of English, compared with 57% of Chinese immigrants, according to the Migration Policy Institute ( mpi ), an American think-tank.

As India's population grows over the coming decades, its people will continue to move overseas to find jobs and escape its heat. Immigration rules in the rich world filter for graduates who can work in professions with demand for more employees, such as medicine and information technology. In 2022 of America's H-1B visas, for skilled workers in “speciality occupations”, such as computer scientists, 73% were won by people born in India.

Many of India's best and brightest seem to prepare themselves to migrate. Consider the findings of a paper soon to be published in the Journal of Development Economics by Prithwiraj Choudhury of Harvard Business School, Ina Ganguli of the University of Massachusetts Amherst and Patrick Gaule of the University of Bristol. It considered students that took the highly competitive entrance exams for the Indian Institutes of Technology, the country's elite engineering schools, in 2010. Eight years later, the researchers found that 36% of the 1,000 top performers had migrated abroad, rising to 62% among the 100 best. Most went to America.

Another study looked at the top 20% of researchers in artificial intelligence (defined as those who had papers accepted for a competitive conference in 2019). It found that 8% did their undergraduate degree in India. But the share of top researchers that now work in India is so small that the researchers did not even record it.

In America almost 80% of the Indian-born population over school age have at least an undergraduate degree, according to number-crunching by Jeanne Batalova at the mpi. Just 50% of the Chinese-born population and 30% of the total population can say the same. It is a similar story in Australia, where almost two-thirds of the Indian-born population over school age, half the Chinese-born and just one-third of the total population has a bachelor's or higher degree. Other rich countries do not collect comparable data.

Softly, softly

Joseph Nye, a Harvard professor who coined the phrase “soft power“, notes that it is not automatically created by the mere presence of a diaspora. “But if you have people in the diaspora who are successful and create a positive image of the country from which they came, that helps their native country.” And, as he notes “ India has a lot of very poor people but they are not the people coming to the United States.”

Indeed Indian migrants are relatively wealthy even in the countries they have moved to. They are the highest-earning migrant group in America, with a median household income of almost $150,000 per year. That is double the national average and well ahead of Chinese migrants, with a median household income of over $95,000. In Australia the median household income among Indian migrants is close to $85,000 per year, compared with an average of roughly $60,000 across all households and $56,500 among the Chinese-born.

The might of the Indian diaspora is increasingly on display at the pinnacle of business and the apex of government. Devesh Kapur and Aditi Mahesh at Johns Hopkins University in Washington, DC , totted up the number of people with Indian roots in top jobs, including those born in India and those whose forebears were. They identified 25 chief executives at S & P 500 companies of Indian descent, up from 11 a decade ago. Given the large number of Indian-origin executives in other senior positions at these companies, that figure is almost sure to rise further.

It is only recently that Indians abroad have begun to win such prestigious posts. Vinod Khosla, co-founder of Sun Microsystems, a computer-maker, recalls how difficult it was for Indian entrepreneurs to raise money in 1980s America. “You were people with a funny accent and a hard to pronounce name and you had to pass a higher bar,” he says. Now Adobe, Alphabet, Google's corporate parent, IBM and Microsoft are all led by people of Indian descent. The deans at three of the five leading business schools, including Harvard Business School, are of Indian descent, too.

In the world of policy and politics, the Indian diaspora is also thriving. The Johns Hopkins researchers have counted 19 people of Indian heritage in Britain's House of Commons, including the prime minister, Rishi Sunak. They identified six in the Australian parliament and five in America's Congress. Vice-President Kamala Harris was brought up by a Tamil Indian mother. And Ajay Banga, born in Pune in India, was selected to lead the World Bank last month after running MasterCard for more than a decade.

The Chinese diaspora is the only other group with comparable influence around the world. The richest man in Malaysia, for example, is Robert Kuok, an ethnic-Chinese businessman whose vast empire includes the Shangri-La hotels. But in Europe and North America, people of Chinese descent do not hold as many influential positions as their Indian counterparts.

Binding Delhi and DC

As America drifts towards a new cold war with China, Westerners increasingly see the country as an enemy. The covid-19 pandemic, which began in the Chinese city of Wuhan, probably made matters worse. In a recent survey of Americans' attitudes by Gallup, a pollster, 84% of respondents said they viewed China mostly or very unfavourably. On India, only 27% of people surveyed held the same negative views.

This mistrust of China percolates through policy. Huawei, a Chinese telecoms-equipment manufacturer suspected in the past of embargo-busting and of being a conduit for Chinese government spying, has been banned in America. Some European countries are following suit. Stringent reviews of foreign investments in American companies on national-security grounds openly target Chinese money in Silicon Valley. Individuals found to be doing China's bidding, including one ex-Harvard professor, have been punished. Indian firms do not face such scrutiny.

The Indian government, by contrast, has been—at least until Mr Modi and his Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party ( BJP ) took over—filled with people whose view of the world had been at least partly shaped by an education in the West. India's first prime minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, studied at Cambridge. Mr Modi's predecessor, Manmohan Singh, studied at both Oxford and Cambridge.

India's claims to be a democratic country steeped in liberal values help its diaspora integrate more readily in the West. The diaspora then binds India to the West in turn. The most stunning example of this emerged in 2008, when America signed an agreement that, in effect, recognised India as a nuclear power, despite its never having signed the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (along with Pakistan and Israel). Lobbying and fundraising by Indian-Americans helped push the deal through America's Congress.

The Indian diaspora gets involved in politics back in India, too. Ahead of the 2014 general election, when Mr Modi first swept to power, one estimate suggests more than 8,000 overseas Indians from Britain and America flew to India to join his campaign. Many more used text messages and social media to turn out BJP votes from afar. They contributed unknown sums of money to the campaign.

Under Mr Modi, India's ties to the West have been tested. In a bid to reassert its status as a non-aligned power, India has refused to condemn Russia's invasion of Ukraine, and stocked up on cheap Russian gas and fertiliser. Government officials spew nationalist rhetoric that pleases right-wing Hindu hotheads. And liberal freedoms are under attack. In March Rahul Gandhi, leader of the opposition Congress party, was disqualified from parliament on a spurious defamation charge after an Indian court convicted him of criminal defamation. Meanwhile journalists are harassed and their offices raided by the authorities.

Overseas Indians help ensure that neither India nor the West gives up on the other. Mr Modi knows he cannot afford to lose their support and that forcing hyphenated Indians to pick sides is out of the question. At a time when China and its friends want to face down a world order set by its rivals, it is vital for the West to keep India on side. Despite its backsliding, India remains invaluable—much like its migrants. ■

; Mon, 12 Jun 2023 19:19:16 GMT /content/feke2dpgf157ogj72ean5tbjkj24vikc https://www.economist.com/international/2023/06/12/indias-diaspora-is-bigger-and-more-influential-than-any-in-history “Kimberly Akimbo” and “Leopoldstadt” triumphed at the Tony Awards

H OSTING AN AWARDS ceremony without a script is no easy task, but Ariana DeBose made it work. The actor, best known for her Oscar-winning turn in Steven Spielberg's “ West Side Story ”, opened the telecast for the 76th Tony Awards by flicking nervously through blank pages in a binder marked “script”. Casting it aside, she then twirled through the United Palace theatre in New York, where the televised ceremony took place on June 11th.

Going script-free was a compromise with the Writers Guild of America ( WGA ), whose members usually supply the monologues and jokes that nudge these events along—but the scriptwriters have been on strike since May 1st. The WGA had called for its Tony-nominated members to boycott the evening and organisers were worried about the threat of protests outside the venue. In the end, though, the show did go on. Stripped of scripted, semi-awkward banter, the streamlined ceremony gave more prominence to musical routines and was a more effective advertisement for live theatre as a result.

Broadway producers rely on the Tonys to get their shows known outside New York, explains Ken Davenport, a Tony award-winning producer whose show “A Beautiful Noise, The Neil Diamond Musical” is now on Broadway. Some reportedly spend between $100,000 and $1m on their campaigns for a Tony (those sums can include the costs of staging musical routines for the broadcast.) Winning an award or being nominated for one boosts sales throughout a production's run, says Gabriel Stelian-Shanks, artistic director of the Drama League, a theatrical association. And as New York's theatre industry recovers from the economic pummelling it took during the pandemic, ensuring enough bums on seats is crucial.

Two productions are in the spotlight this year. “Kimberly Akimbo”, a charming musical about a 16-year-old in the body of a septuagenarian, took home five awards, including the prize for Best Musical. Meanwhile “ Leopoldstadt ”, Tom Stoppard's drama about the Holocaust, won four Tonys including the trophy for Best Play. Several Tonys went to shows that comment on the issues of the day: “Leopoldstadt” and “Parade” both confront anti-Semitism, while “Prima Facie”, starring Jodie Comer, tackles sexual assault. There were also history-making awards for two non-binary actors, J. Harrison Ghee (“ Some Like It Hot ”) and Alex Newell, (“Shucked”).

The triumphant ceremony reflected the fact that Broadway, after its first full season since the pandemic, has much to celebrate. Audiences are returning, though numbers have yet to reach pre-pandemic levels, according to the Broadway League, a national trade association. Theatregoers are, on average, paying more for tickets, too, which suggests increased demand.

Yet the already high costs of putting on a show are rising still. For some productions, they have become prohibitive, which is why “Phantom of the Opera” closed in April after 35 years on Broadway. Producers must contend with the effects of inflation, supply-chain problems and the lingering impacts of covid-19, which has forced directors to hire more understudies in case a cast member falls ill.

Theatre has always been a risky venture: only around one in five productions on Broadway recoup their investment. Mounting a musical requires especially deep pockets; it can cost between $10m and $20m. These steep overheads are why producers often revive popular shows with celebrity performers, as they will guarantee audiences. For example, “The Music Man”, starring Hugh Jackman, regularly broke box-office records before the musical closed in January. Punters fork out $175 on average to see Josh Groban in “Sweeney Todd” and Lea Michele in “Funny Girl”, among the dearest tickets on Broadway.

“A new musical is always a gamble,” reckons Susan Stroman, a five-time Tony-Award-winning director and choreographer who was nominated this year for “New York, New York”. Still, it is one that ambitious producers seem willing to take. Of the 40 shows on Broadway this season, 28 were original productions. Mike Bosner, one of the producers of “Shucked”, a new musical, admits that marketing a show without a star or built-in brand can feel like pushing a boulder up a hill. “There's clearly an audience out there who's willing to spend money on shows,” he says. Producers just need to figure out how to persuade them to take the plunge on a new performance. It is just as well, then, that the show about corn, love and deceit earned nine Tony nominations and received one award. ■
